problems.description:
As you create functions for SingPath, remember that they all will need to be fruitful functions.  This will allow SingPath to actually test your functions.  

Create the function square() that takes an integer or float as a parameter and returns the square of the parameter.

I've given the complete function for this problem, you just need to remove the comment markings.
problems.examples:
This is the first problem where you will see multiple tests with multiple values.  You need to make sure your function works for all of these tests.

>>> square(3) 
 9
>>> square(8.5)
 72.25
>>> square(1.001)
 1.002001
problems.name: Functions

problems.description: Create a function named increment() that takes a number as a parameter and returns the number increased by one.  All you need to do is type in the expression after the word 'return'.
problems.name: Increment

problems.description: Create a function called double_word() that takes a string as a parameter and returns the string duplicated.
problems.name: Double String

problems.description: You need to generalize the function double_word() so that it takes two parameters, a string and a number.  It should return the string repeated the given number of times.
problems.name: Repeat String

problems.description: Python comes with many modules or libraries of functions and values.  You can access the functions and values in these modules by importing the module.  One of the modules you will often need is the math module.  It has many functions and values.  For this problem you will use the module to calculate the area of a circle given the radius.  You will notice that you can get the value of pi using the syntax math.pi.  Finish the formula.
problems.name: Math Module

problems.description:
Angles can be measured in degrees or in radians.  For most math functions you need to use radians rather than degrees.  

You need to create a function radian() that takes an angle in degrees as input and converts it to radians.  This calculation is done by multiplying by pi and dividing by 180.
problems.name: Radians

problems.description: Create a function that calculates the cosine of an angle (in degrees).  The math module contains a function math.cos that uses radians to calculate the cosine.  You will need to convert the angle to radians first, then use the cos function to calculate cosine.  Remember, you have to multiply the degrees by pi/180 to convert to radians.
problems.name: Math Functions - cosine

problems.description:
Functions may be called using keyword arguments of the form keyword = value.  An argument list must have any positional arguments first, then any keyword arguments which must a parameter name.

A function sandwich is started below, type of bread is the first argument followed by 2 optional keyword arguments for meat and cheese.  Notice that both meat and cheese are given default values. If cheese is None omit cheese from the sandwich.
 See the Example for output formatting
problems.examples:
>>> sandwich('wheat')
 'wheat bread sandwich with turkey'

>>> sandwich('white', meat='ham', cheese='American')
 'white bread sandwich with ham and American cheese'
 
>>> sandwich('white', cheese='American', meat='ham')
 'white bread sandwich with ham and American cheese'

>>> sandwich('rye','ham','Swiss')
 'rye bread sandwich with ham and Swiss cheese'

>>> sandwich('white', cheese='provolone')
 'white bread sandwich with turkey and provolone cheese'
problems.name: Keyword Arguments

problems.description: Hawker Auntie sells chicken and fish curry puffs for S$1.20 and S$1.40 each respectively. When a customer asks for curry puff, it can be assumed they mean chicken puff. Help hawker Auntie to find the right price for her sales, by creating a function called CurryPuff.
problems.name: Find Curry Puff Price

problems.description:
In many ways functions can be treated in the same way as variables.  They can even be passed as arguments into another function.  

For this problem, you need to create a function called double_result() which takes two arguments.  The first argument is a function and the second is a value.  Your function needs to call the function that is passed to it, passing the value as an argument.  Double the result and return that value.

You do not need to write any other functions.
problems.name: Function Caller

problems.description:
A semantic error occurs when a function runs without problems but returns an incorrect result.  Remove the semantic error to make the program operate as expected.

>>> add_one(5)
15
problems.name: Semantic Error

problems.description: Create a function called subtract_last_digit that takes two parameters and returns the first number minus the last digit of the second number
problems.name: Subtract Last Digit

problems.description:
When you create new functions it is important to create comments to show what the parameters are doing.  This is done by putting a triple quoted string at the first line of the function.

Create a function called difference that calculates the difference between two inputs.  

Be sure to create a doc string to give instructions about how the function needs to work. I've shown a simple example of a doc string below.
problems.examples:
def printme(a):
    '''takes an input and prints it'''
    print a

>>> difference(7,5)
 2
>>> difference(7,15)
 -8
>>> type(difference.__doc__)
 "<type 'str'>"
problems.name: Doc Strings

problems.description:
Write a function named right_justify that takes a string named s as a parameter and returns the string with enough leading spaces so that the last letter of the string is in column 40 of the display.

You will need to use the len function again.
problems.name: Right Justify

problems.description: What happens when your Math teacher asks you to add from 1 to 10 and expects an answer real fast? Write a function named addition that takes in a parameter that adds up numbers using the formula: (x*(x+1))/2.
problems.name: Additions!

problems.description: Write a function that takes in 2 argument; x and y. If either x is a string and y is an int or vice versa, return the repeated strings. If not, just return the concatenated string or sum of the numbers.   You can use the isinstance function to determine if a variable is of a certain type.
problems.examples:
>>> str_int(-2,5)
 3
>>> str_int(2.1,3.3)
 5.4
>>> str_int('hit','miss')
 'hitmiss'
>>> str_int('hit',2)
 'hithit'
>>> str_int(3,'miss')
 'missmissmiss'
>>> str_int(3.5,'hit')
 '3.5hit'
problems.name: str_int

problems.description: Economic Order Quantity is a model to determine the order quantity to optimize your inventory level in production scheduling. It states that this optimal quantity is dependent on fixed setup/ordering cost (S), holding cost (H), and quantity demanded of that product (D). To be more specific: Optimal quantity equals to the square root of (2*D*S)/H. Create a method to calculate this! Note: Round your answer to the nearest integer.
problems.name: EOQ Calculator

problems.description: Create a Function to find out the volume of a circle based cylinder. It will take in 2 parameters: the radius of circle and the height of cylinder.  (Be sure that you use enough digits of pi as the tests are done to a higher accuracy than displayed.  Note: python has a built in value for pi if you know how to use it.)
problems.name: Volume of Cylinder

problems.description: In this problem, you need to calculate the area of a circle given the radius. The area of circle is "pi" times the radius squared.  You can use the pi in math module. Your answer should be accurate to 6 decimal places (use the built-in round function).
problems.name: Area of Circle

problems.description: Unlike Java, in Python we do not need to state type of parameter passed into the method. Although this is good, there are times we need to know or check the type of the parameter that was passed in. Create a function that will return the type of the parameter that is passed in as a String. Hint - Python built-in library reference
problems.examples:
>>> identifyType(1)
 "<type 'int'>"

>>> identifyType(1.0)
 "<type 'float'>"

>>> identifyType("I'm a String")
 "<type 'str'>"

>>> identifyType([1,2,3,4,5])
 "<type 'list'>"

>>> identifyType({2:2,1:1,3:3})
 "<type 'dict'>"
problems.name: Identify parameter type

problems.description: Create a function taking in 2 parameters, the base length and height of a triangle, return the area.
problems.name: Calculate the Area of a Triangle
